item.title: iOS Dev Weekly - Issue 512 - Jun 18th 2021
item.description:
Comment

I didn‚Äôt know quite how to feel as I watched Kieran Senior talk about reviewing code and dealing with pull requests inside Xcode this week. At first, I was nothing but impressed when I realised Xcode now integrates with both GitHub and BitBucket pull requests natively inside Xcode. I want to review code this way! The web-based representation of a pull request on GitHub is good, but it‚Äôll never compete with looking code in Xcode.

So, I opened up a project in Xcode 13, and sure enough, my active pull requests with comments, approvals, and everything else are all available. It‚Äôs a great implementation, and I‚Äôd love to send my congratulations to everyone involved.

Yet, I also realised I would probably never use the feature again after testing it. üò∞ If you‚Äôre anything like me, source control isn‚Äôt just for files edited by Xcode. I interact with git in every project I work on, and Xcode is only the best tool for Swift projects. If I need a standalone tool to work with git, I don‚Äôt want to learn the one inside Xcode as well, no matter how good it is. I only have limited brainpower, and I‚Äôm can only master one source control tool.

This is the dilemma of building an IDE vs a set of standalone tools, and knowing where to draw the line is tricky. Do I want my debugger as part of my IDE? Definitely. Do I want my interface layout tool in the IDE? Again, you probably do. Do I want source control? For me, it‚Äôs a no, and I‚Äôd guess I‚Äôm not alone. It‚Äôs a balancing act, and Xcode has been heading towards integrated IDE and away from being a collection of standalone tools for a long time.

If Apple had made this a standalone tool that worked well with Xcode rather than as a part of it, would it have pulled me away from my source code control tool of choice? Maybe!

I think we can all agree it‚Äôs a well-implemented feature, but I can see how things happened this way. Making a whole new tool is a much bigger decision than enhancing a feature in an existing product. A new tool needs a new team, and that team has to justify its existence. They wouldn‚Äôt try and sell a tool like this, so why make it? Yes, maybe it would bring people who didn‚Äôt do native development to their developer tool, but it‚Äôs far from a straightforward decision.

I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd ever get to see anything I had worked on in a WWDC session presentation. That‚Äôs a privilege even if you work inside Apple. It‚Äôs pretty much unheard of if you don‚Äôt.

And yet, this week, it happened. ü§Ø

It began when I started receiving messages and DMs from people saying, ‚ÄúDid you just see the mention of a package index on that slide?‚Äù during the Platforms State of the Union. I hadn‚Äôt even seen it, but a quick screenshot proved it! I did wonder for a few seconds whether we might be about to be Sherlocked, but something far more exciting was on the table.

It came in the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs new in Swift‚Äù session on Tuesday. 2m45s into the session, Nicole Jacque begins talking about Swift Packages, and suddenly, there‚Äôs a screenshot of the package index! Right there in a WWDC session! I couldn‚Äôt quite believe it.

I want to say a heartfelt thank you to everyone who was involved in making this happen. I have to think this decision wasn‚Äôt taken lightly, and it‚Äôs so lovely to see that people inside Apple think what we‚Äôre working on is important enough to include alongside their own work. The Swift Package Index remains the most exciting part of my work every week, and I can‚Äôt wait to see where we take it over the next year.

So, that was my highlight of this week, but that was far from the only exciting thing that happened! As usual, I‚Äôm not going to try and cover every announcement or new API today. We have several months for that!

It‚Äôs almost WWDC time! üöÄüòçüéâ

Looking around Twitter and the web this week, I see two very different narratives from the community about this year‚Äôs conference. On the one hand, I see the usual excitement, anticipation, and hope for Xcode to be better at understanding Swift. On the other, I see more unrest and frustration in the Apple developer community than I‚Äôve ever seen before. This post from Marco Arment is a good summary of how many people feel.

I think some of you are hoping for an App Store focused announcement at the conference. Maybe all of this pressure from lawsuits, anti-trust investigations, and the community will force Apple‚Äôs hand, and they‚Äôll relent on some aspect of the App Store?

I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to happen. First, I don‚Äôt think now is the right time for Apple to make any drastic business changes to the App Store. The Apple/Epic trial may be over, but the verdict is still weeks or months away and making changes now would send all sorts of awkward messages.

It‚Äôs more than that, though. I don‚Äôt think this is fixed by ‚Äúsimply‚Äù making more changes to the App Store. This level of unrest doesn‚Äôt go away with another tweak to the percentages or by enabling side-loading. As Marco says in his article, this is much more about how Apple treats third party developers generally.

To be clear, I‚Äôm talking about Apple as an entity here, not about individual employees. In my experience, Apple employees are genuine, kind, empathetic individuals who care deeply about developers. Unfortunately, as a company, it can feel very different.

There‚Äôs no quick fix for this and no single announcement that makes it go away. If Apple wants their relationship with developers to improve, it‚Äôll take consistent change over time, starting close to the top. It‚Äôs not just about the App Store terms and conditions.

It‚Äôs a shame because we‚Äôre in the midst of so much tremendously exciting technical work from the company, and it‚Äôs partly overshadowed. I‚Äôd much rather be talking about that!

item.title: iOS Dev Weekly - Issue 509 - May 28th 2021
item.description:
Comment

I still (just about! üë¥) remember the first time I came across asynchronous programming. I assumed, incorrectly, that when I called into the concurrent code, execution would continue in my calling function after it had completed. Of course, I was as wrong then as I often am now!

I feel like programming languages are finally catching up with my naive expectations as async/await syntax becomes more standard across a wide range of languages. The great news is, that group of languages will soon include Swift.

I started thinking about this topic after reading Alejandro Martinez‚Äôs post on Swift concurrency and watching the three videos that accompany it. He covers three distinct parts of the Swift concurrency story in detail, and I learned a lot from watching them. I‚Äôm sure you will too.

Over the years, I feel like I‚Äôve seen programming languages fight a constant battle against complexity as the hardware, operating systems, and user expectations push languages and frameworks to evolve. As the battle progresses, complexity goes through advances and retreats and for every step forward that languages make, there‚Äôs complexity lying in wait trying to gain new footholds.

For example, manual memory management was a huge advance for the complexity army until the combined forces of reference counting, garbage collection, and eventually, automatic reference counting pushed it to retreat. The last time I wrote about scam subscription apps, I finished by saying this:

Communication about what Apple is doing and how they think about these problems would be a huge step in the right direction.

So, when Apple published a press release this week titled ‚ÄúApp Store stopped more than $1.5 billion in potentially fraudulent transactions in 2020‚Äù followed by 1,300 words about the measures they take to counter scam apps and fraudulent developers, I should have been thrilled.

Yes, I wish it hadn‚Äôt taken the discovery phase of a major lawsuit to prompt them to make a statement, but I am happy that they‚Äôre talking about it.

The statistics they quote are impressive, too. As I suspected, there‚Äôs lots of work going on behind the scenes. $1.5B of prevented fraudulent transactions. 150,000 spam apps rejected. 470,000 developer accounts terminated. 250 million ratings and reviews removed. That‚Äôs a lot! What a great job they‚Äôve been doing. Right?

That‚Äôs certainly the message of this press release, but I‚Äôm afraid it did not make my wishes come true. My disappointment comes from how they talk about these problems. This is a press release, so it‚Äôs not a surprise that it paints a positive picture of the company, but they talk about these issues like they are completely solved and have been on top of the problem from the beginning. There‚Äôs no mention of ‚Äúwe have a lot of work to do‚Äù or any hint that the App Store isn‚Äôt a perfect fortress of impeccable moderation and scrutiny. The work they are doing is impressive, as I knew it would be, but the problem is a very long way from being solved. In fact, to ‚Äúsolve‚Äù it shouldn‚Äôt be the goal. To genuinely keep on top of it should be.

All of the talk about ‚Äúrelentless steps forward to combat these risks‚Äù would sound much more authentic if the scam apps were harder to find. Take a look at this tweet from Kosta Eleftheriou, for example. It‚Äôs a screenshot of an app he created as a solo developer without access to any internal Apple systems, and it shows a list of problematic apps. It‚Äôs clear that the problem is not solved, and Apple is not keeping up.

I wish Apple could find a way to be more honest about some of the more negative aspects of the App Store in their developer communications. Yes, a press release isn‚Äôt the correct venue for that, especially with all the lawsuits, but it must be possible. If not, it‚Äôs time to shut us up by living up to the claims made in this press release. I think we‚Äôd all be happy with that as a solution instead. üëç

Something struck me as I watched the M1 chip appear in more hardware on Tuesday. It won‚Äôt be long until the whole Mac lineup has the same internals.

The ‚Äúlow‚Äù end of the Apple silicon Mac lineup now looks complete. The smaller laptops, Mac mini, and smaller iMac all have the same chip inside them, the M1. Yes, some of them have one less GPU core, but that‚Äôs such a minor difference it‚Äôs barely worth mentioning.

But what about the ‚ÄúPro‚Äù Macs? What about more than 16Gb RAM and high-end GPUs, and all the other things ‚ÄúPro‚Äù users want? I feel pretty confident that Apple will fall into the same consistent cycle for M-series chips that they have been so consistent with while producing the A-series. September will almost certainly bring us an A15 with the new iPhone, and I‚Äôd bet an M2 will accompany it with the capability for more memory and story around better or dedicated GPUs. I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll see the entire range of M1 upgraded to M2 chips immediately, but I think we‚Äôll see it happen before the M3 arrives. Maybe the highest-end machines will get more cores via an M2X or similar, but wouldn‚Äôt it be great if the whole Mac lineup had their chips upgraded every year, just like the iPhone and iPad do?

Do you know what that would mean? It would no longer be possible to buy a bad Mac! Just pick the form factor you‚Äôd like, and that‚Äôs it. Do you want a small laptop with a keyboard? MacBook Air. Want a desktop with a built-in screen? The iMac is for you. Which machine is faster for X, or Y task? That is no longer a valid question. It would also mean that there wouldn‚Äôt be a bad time to buy a Mac, as you‚Äôd never be more than a year behind the latest upgrades.

Why am I talking about this? Especially when I try not to make predictions or dwell on what might be coming next. üò¨

The promise of SwiftUI is the software equivalent of the Apple silicon chips. You can‚Äôt pick the wrong framework, and your code will (largely) be compatible with any Apple platform. Just choose a platform (or platforms) you‚Äôd like to target and start creating.

We may not quite be there today, but we‚Äôre moving closer to that reality with every passing year. SwiftUI is the Apple silicon of software frameworks. ü§©

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the only one who has a constant stream of ideas related to software I either work on now, or may work on in the future. The quality of my ideas varies wildly, and it‚Äôs often the worst ideas that shout loudest at me to drop everything and start working on them. üòÖ You‚Äôll never be perfect at knowing where to focus your attention, or at least I‚Äôve resigned myself to the fact that I‚Äôll never be perfect at it, but it‚Äôs an important thing to keep in mind.

I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about the maturity of ideas this week, mostly because of this week‚Äôs release of Sourcery Pro by Krzysztof Zab≈Çocki. Would this app be as good as it is without the years of thought, development, and iteration that went into Sourcery? Almost certainly not. That experience drove the feature set and workflow, and the app is much better for it.

But does every idea need to be deliberated on for years? Nope! Some ideas benefit from a quick MVP and experimentation. For example, this newsletter. I had the idea to do it, and around a week later I sent the first issue.

It‚Äôs hard to advise on this topic, but I think choosing what to pursue often comes down to how complex/significant the task is. I made the right decision to move quickly when deciding to start iOS Dev Weekly as the opportunity cost was small, and I took things much more slowly when considering whether to build the Swift Package Index.

The original idea for building a package search engine popped into my head around two years before the launch of the index site, and a year before the SwiftPM Library. I let the idea stew for a long while before starting as I knew the undertaking was significant.
